author: Paul de Barros
title: A jazz tribute to Richard Hugo, bard of the Duwamish
text:
Richard Hugo, who grew up in White Center, taught in Montana and achieved some success as a poet during his troubled life (1923-1982), has inspired numerous local projects, among them the Capitol Hill literary center named after him and a 2010 book of photographs by Mary Randlett and poet Frances McCue.
Now, the bard of the Duwamish has prompted an exquisitely beautiful chamber jazz work for septet, “Some Places Are Forever Afternoon: 11 Places for Richard Hugo,” by Seattle’s Wayne Horvitz, who offers the Seattle premiere of the piece Saturday (Oct. 10) at Cornish College of the Arts’ Poncho Concert Hall.
The performance is one of four Earshot Jazz Festival concerts featuring Horvitz’s work. The others are a reprise of “Forever Afternoon” on Sunday (Oct. 11) — appropriately enough, at the White Center Field House; an orchestral piece with another Hugo-inspired title, “Those Who Remain,” featuring guitarist Bill Frisell, part of the Seattle Symphony Orchestra’s Sonic Evolution series on Oct. 29; and a full evening of the pianist’s music Nov. 12 at the Royal Room, in Columbia City.
Concert preview ‘Some Places Are Forever Afternoon: 11 Places for Richard Hugo’ By Wayne Horvitz, 8 p.m. Saturday, Oct. 10, at Poncho Concert Hall, Cornish College of the Arts, 710 E. Roy St., Seattle; $14-$28 (206-547-6763 or earshot.org ).
6 p.m. Sunday, Oct. 11, White Center Fieldhouse, 1321 S.W. 102nd St., Seattle; free (206-547-6763 or earshot.org ).
As always with Horvitz, “Forever Afternoon” treads to the left of conventional expectations, with the music standing in oblique relation to the poems. These are not song settings, nor are they even direct musical analogues of Hugo’s words. To the contrary, Horvitz took his inspiration from an evocative line in each poem — which he used as titles — then let his imagination run free.

Hugo loved jazz. Horvitz found the improvisatory quality in his writing attractive — “just letting one line lead to another,” as he put it. Indeed, in poems like “Three Stops to Ten Sleep,” “Death of the Kapowsin Tavern” and “Degrees of Gray in Philipsburg” — which sports Hugo’s best line ever, “The car that brought you here still runs” — Hugo often begins thoughts midline, a rhythmic device Horvitz echoes in his sometimes staggered writing.
“There’s a kind of layering,” he said. “One thing starts before something else hasn’t quite ended.”
On “Last Place There,” a section that has no poetic counterpart, soloists improvise in four-four time over a background figure of jagged, odd-numbered measures in three. On “All Weather is Yours No Matter How Vulgar,” from the poem “Fairfield,” Horvitz slides into honky-tonk, boogie-woogie piano.
To prepare, Horvitz took a research trip with his daughter, poet and photographer Nica Horvitz, through the Montana country that provided the backdrop for much of Hugo’s late-career writing. 
Their journey included Hugo’s fishing cabin but also the deserted ex-boomtowns and depressing bars where he often drank to excess. Nica Horvitz’s photos appear in a booklet with a new CD of the piece and also on the project blog, at foreverafternoonblog.wordpress.com . 
Both Horvitzes nicely capture the play of darkness and light, optimism and depression, that course through Hugo’s work.
“That wasn’t such a leap for me,” Horvitz said, laughing. “I’m sort of that way, anyway. I’m extremely nervous and also basically an optimist.”
To create that contrast, Horvitz combined members from two of his groups, the jazz band Sweeter Than the Day, and chamber-music outfit Gravitas.
The colors and feelings he pulls from Ron Miles’ trumpet, Sara Schoenbeck’s bassoon, Peggy Lee’s cello and Tim Young’s electric guitar — with Keith Lowe (bass) and Eric Eagle (drums) holding down the rhythm fort — are alternately warm, floating, swinging, nervous, dark, joyous, pained, ecstatic, sad, prayerful — in short, true to the range of Hugo’s palette.
At the performance, each poem will be read after its correspondent music by poet McCue or Horvitz’s wife, singer-songwriter Robin Holcomb.
The last performance on this tour is in White Center, where Hugo began, and the premiere was in Montana, where he died. 
“It wasn’t planned that way,” said Horvitz.
Somehow that’s in keeping with the improvising and contrary spirit of both the poet and the composer.
Note: National Public Radio’s “Jazz Night in America” will be filming the Cornish performance.
